title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

text: IV.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: How Herne the Hunter showed the Earl of Surrey the Fair
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: Geraldine in a Vision.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: On the third day after Surrey's imprisonment in the keep, he was removed
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: to the Norman Tower. The chamber allotted him was square, tolerably
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: lofty, and had two narrow-pointed windows on either side, looking on
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: the one hand into the upper quadrangle, and on the other into the middle
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: ward. At the same time permission was accorded him to take exercise on
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: the battlements of the Round Tower, or within the dry and grassy moat at
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: its foot.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: The Fair Geraldine, he was informed, had been sent to the royal palace
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: at Greenwich; but her absence occasioned him little disquietude, because
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: he knew, if she had remained at Windsor, he would not have been allowed
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: to see her.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: On the same day that Surrey was removed to the Norman Tower, the Duke
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: of Richmond quitted the castle without assigning any motive for his
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: departure, or even taking leave of his friend. At first some jealous
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: mistrust that he might be gone to renew his suit to the Fair
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: Geraldine troubled the earl; but he strongly combated the feeling, as
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: calculated, if indulged, to destroy his tranquillity; and by fixing
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: his thoughts sedulously on other subjects, he speedily succeeded in
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: overcoming it.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: On that night, while occupied in a translation of the Aeneid which he
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: had commenced, he remained at his task till a late hour. The midnight
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: bell had tolled, when, looking up, he was startled by perceiving a tall
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: figure standing silent and motionless beside him.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: Independently of the difficulty of accounting for its presence, the
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: appearance of the figure was in itself sufficiently appalling. It was
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: above the ordinary stature, and was enveloped in a long black cloak,
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: while a tall, conical black cap, which added to its height, and
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: increased the hideousness of its features, covered its head.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: For a few minutes Surrey remained gazing at the figure in mute
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: astonishment, during which it maintained the same motionless posture. At
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: length he was able to murmur forth the interrogation, "Who art thou?"
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "A friend," replied the figure, in a sepulchral tone.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "Are you a man or spirit?" demanded Surrey.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "It matters not--I am a friend," rejoined the figure.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "On what errand come you here?" asked Surrey.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "To serve you," replied the figure; "to liberate you. You shall go hence
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: with me, if you choose."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "On what condition?" rejoined Surrey.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "We will speak of that when we are out of the castle, and on the green
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: sod of the forest," returned the figure.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "You tempt in vain," cried Surrey. "I will not go with you. I recognise
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: in you the demon hunter Herne." The figure laughed hollowly--so hollowly
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: that Surrey's flesh crept upon his bones.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "You are right, lord of Surrey," he said; "I am Herne the Hunter. You
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: must join me. Sir Thomas Wyat is already one of my band."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "You lie, false fiend!" rejoined Surrey. "Sir Thomas Wyat is in France."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "It is you who lie, lord of Surrey," replied Herne; "Sir Thomas Wyat is
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: now in the great park. You shall see him in a few minutes, if you will
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: come with me."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "I disbelieve you, tempter!" cried Surrey indignantly. "Wyat is too good
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: a Christian, and too worthy a knight, to league with a demon."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: Again Herne laughed bitterly.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "Sir Thomas Wyat told you he would seek me out," said the demon. "He did
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: so, and gave himself to me for Anne Boleyn."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "But you have no power over her, demon?" cried Surrey, shuddering.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "You will learn whether I have or not, in due time," replied Herne. "Do
title: Windsor Castle

text: THE storm which had fallen so heavily on the castle had likewise visited
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: the lake, and alarmed the inmates of the little dwelling on its banks.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: Both the forester and his grand-daughter were roused from their beds,
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: and they sat together in the chief apartment of the cottage, listening
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: to the awful rolling of the thunder, and watching the blue flashing of
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: the lightning. The storm was of unusually long duration, and continued
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: for more than an hour with unintermitted violence. It then paused; the
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: frequent. During the storm Mabel continued on her knees, addressing the
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: her grandfather; but the old forester, though evidently much alarmed,
title: Windsor Castle

text: uttered not a single supplication, but remained sitting in his chair
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: with a sullen, scared look. As the thunder died away, he recovered
title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: granddaughter. In this he had partially succeeded, and was urging her
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle

text: posture. Another dreadful half-hour, marked by a succession of terrible
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: ventured to address her old relative.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle

text: grandfather?"

author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle

author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: Made aware by the clangour of the lock, and Fenwolf's exulting laughter,
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: of the snare in which he had been caught, Sir Thomas Wyat instantly
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: sprang from his hiding-place, and rushed to the door; but being framed
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: of the stoutest oak, and strengthened with plates of iron, it defied all
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: his efforts, nerved as they were by rage and despair, to burst it
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: open. Mabel's shrieks, as she was dragged away, reached his ears, and
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: increased his anguish; and he called out loudly to her companions to
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: return, but his vociferations were only treated with derision.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: Finding it useless to struggle further, Wyat threw himself upon the
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: bench, and endeavoured to discover some means of deliverance from his
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: present hazardous position. He glanced round the cell to see whether
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: there was any other outlet than the doorway, but he could discern none,
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: except a narrow grated loophole opening upon the passage, and contrived,
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: doubtless, for the admission of air to the chamber. No dungeon could be
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: more secure.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: Raising the lamp, he examined every crevice, but all seemed solid stone.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: The recess in which he had taken shelter proved to be a mere hollow in
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: the wall. In one corner lay a small straw pallet, which, no doubt, had
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: formed the couch of Mabel; and this, together with the stone bench and
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: rude table of the same material, constituted the sole furniture of the
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: place.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: Having taken this careful survey of the cell, Wyat again sat down upon
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: the bench with the conviction that escape was out of the question; and
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: he therefore endeavoured to prepare himself for the worst, for it was
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: more than probable he would be allowed to perish of starvation. To a
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: fiery nature like his, the dreadful uncertainty in which he was placed
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: was more difficult of endurance than bodily torture. And he was destined
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: to endure it long. Many hours flew by, during which nothing occurred to
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: relieve the terrible monotony of his situation. At length, in spite of
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: his anxiety, slumber stole upon him unawares; but it was filled with
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: frightful visions.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: How long he slept he knew not, but when he awoke, he found that the
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: cell must have been visited in the interval, for there was a manchet of
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: bread, part of a cold neck of venison, and a flask of wine on the table.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: It was evident, therefore, that his captors did not mean to starve him,
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: and yielding to the promptings of appetite, he attacked the provisions,
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: determined to keep strict watch when his gaoler should next visit him.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: The repast finished, he again examined the cell, but with no better
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: success than before; and he felt almost certain, from the position in
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: which the bench was placed, that the visitor had not found entrance
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: through the door.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: After another long and dreary interval, finding that sleep was stealing
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: upon him fast, he placed the bench near the door, and leaned his back
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: against the latter, certain that in this position he should be awakened
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: if any one attempted to gain admittance in that way. His slumber was
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: again disturbed by fearful dreams; and he was at length aroused by a
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: touch upon the shoulder, while a deep voice shouted his own name in her
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: ears.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: Starting to his feet, and scarcely able to separate the reality from
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: the hideous phantasms that had troubled him, he found that the door was
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: still fastened, and the bench unremoved, while before him stood Herne
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: the Hunter.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "Welcome again to my cave, Sir Thomas Wyat!" cried the demon, with a
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: mocking laugh. "I told you, on the night of the attempt upon the king,
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: that though you escaped him, you would not escape me. And so it has come
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: to pass. You are now wholly in my power, body and soul--ha! ha!"
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "I defy you, false fiend," replied Wyat. "I was mad enough to proffer
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: you my soul on certain conditions; but they have never been fulfilled."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "They may yet be so," rejoined Herne.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "No," replied Wyat, "I have purged my heart from the fierce and
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: unhallowed passion that swayed it. I desire no assistance from you."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "If you have changed your mind, that is nought to me," rejoined the demon
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: derisively--"I shall hold you to your compact."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "Again I say I renounce you, infernal spirit!" cried Wyat; "you may
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: destroy my body--but you can work no mischief to my soul."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "You alarm yourself without reason, good Sir Thomas," replied Herne, in
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: a slightly sneering tone. "I am not the malignant being you suppose
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: me; neither am I bent upon fighting the battles of the enemy of mankind
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: against Heaven. I may be leagued with the powers of darkness, but I have
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: no wish to aid them; and I therefore leave you to take care of your soul
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: in your own way. What I desire from you is your service while living.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: Now listen to the conditions I have to propose. You must bind yourself
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: by a terrible oath, the slightest infraction of which shall involve the
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: perdition of the soul you are so solicitous to preserve, not to disclose
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: aught you may see, or that may be imparted to you here. You must also
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: swear implicit obedience to me in all things--to execute any secret
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: commissions, of whatever nature, I may give you--to bring associates
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: to my band--and to join me in any enterprise I may propose. This oath
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: taken, you are free. Refuse it, and I leave you to perish."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "I do refuse it," replied Wyat boldly. "I would die a thousand deaths
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: rather than so bind myself. Neither do I fear being left to perish here.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: You shall not quit this cell without me."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "You are a stout soldier, Sir Thomas Wyat," rejoined the demon, with a
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: scornful laugh; "but you are scarcely a match for Herne the Hunter, as
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: you will find, if you are rash enough to make the experiment. Beware!"
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: he exclaimed, in a voice of thunder, observing the knight lay his hand
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: upon his sword, "I am invulnerable, and you will, therefore, vainly
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: strike at me. Do not compel me to use the dread means, which I could
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: instantly employ, to subject you to my will. I mean you well, and would
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: rather serve than injure you. But I will not let you go, unless you
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: league yourself with me. Swear, therefore, obedience to me, and depart
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: hence to your friends, Surrey and Richmond, and tell them you have
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: failed to find me."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "You know, then, of our meeting?" exclaimed Wyat.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "Perfectly well," laughed Herne. "It is now eventide, and at midnight
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: the meeting will take place in the forester's hut. If you attend it not,
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: I will. They will be my prisoners as well as you. To preserve yourself
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: and save them, you must join me."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "Before I return an answer," said Wyat, "I must know what has become of
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: Mabel Lyndwood."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "Mabel Lyndwood is nought to you, Sir Thomas," rejoined Herne coldly.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "She is so much to me that I will run a risk for her which I would not
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: run for myself," replied Wyat. "If I promise obedience to you, will you
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: liberate her? will you let her depart with me?"
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "No," said Herne peremptorily. "Banish all thoughts of her from your
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: breast. You will never behold her again. I will give you time for
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: reflection on my proposal. An hour before midnight I shall return, and
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: if I find you in the same mind, I abandon you to your fate."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: And with these words he stepped back towards the lower end of the cell.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: Wyat instantly sprang after him, but before he could reach him a flash
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: of fire caused him to recoil, and to his horror and amazement, he beheld
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: the rock open, and yield a passage to the retreating figure.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: When the sulphureous smoke, with which the little cell was filled, had
title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: could not find the slightest trace of a secret outlet, and therefore
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: concluded that the disappearance of the demon had been effected by
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: magic.

text: How Mabel escaped from the Cave with Sir Thomas Wyat.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: by without the opportunity of escape, for which she sighed, occurring to
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: her. As night drew on, she became more anxious, and at last expressed a
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: that the lock had got strained, and the bolts would not move, and he was
title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: which he took a seat.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: guard with Fenwolf, but this the other positively declined, and leaning
title: Windsor Castle

text: against the door, disposed himself to slumber. Tristram then threw
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: By-and-by, however, when Fenwolf's heavy breathing gave token of the
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: soundness of his sleep, Tristram raised himself upon his elbow, and
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: gazed round. The lamp placed upon the table imperfectly illumined the
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: cavern, for the fire which had been lighted to cook the evening meal
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: had gone out completely. Getting up cautiously, and drawing his
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: hunting-knife, the old man crept towards Fenwolf, apparently with the
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: intent of stabbing him, but he suddenly changed his resolution, and
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: dropped his arm.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: At that moment, as if preternaturally warned, Fenwolf opened his eyes,
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: and seeing the old forester standing by, sprang upon him, and seized him
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: by the throat.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: leading to Wyat's cell, and was about to rouse you, when you awakened of
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: your own accord, probably disturbed by the noise."

author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "It may be," replied Fenwolf, satisfied with the excuse, and
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: relinquishing his grasp. "I fancied I heard something in my dreams. But
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: come with me to Wyat's cell. I will not leave you here."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: And snatching up the lamp, he hurried with Tristram into the passage.

author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: who had overheard what had passed; and so hurriedly did she issue
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: conceal herself in an adjoining passage, when Fenwolf rushed back into
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: the cavern.
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "It was a false alarm," he cried. "I saw Sir Thomas Wyat in his cell
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: through the loop-hole, and I have brought the key away with me. But I am
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: sure I heard a noise here."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "It must have been mere fancy," said Tristram. "All is as we left it."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: "It seems so, certes," replied Fenwolf doubtfully. "But I will make
title: Windsor Castle

text: sure."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: that she was safe. Persuaded that he heard some sound in the chamber,
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: In less than ten minutes he was again asleep. Mabel then emerged from
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: her concealment, and cautiously approached Tristram, who feigned, also,
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: to slumber. As she approached him, he rose noiselessly to his feet.

author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle

text: the lock. But come with me. I will lead you out of the cavern."
title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle

text: from under the table, signed to Tristram to remain where he was, and
title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle
author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

text: the cell.

author: Ainsworth, William Harrison

title: Windsor Castle

title: Windsor Castle
